awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Non-invasive, multimode, hand-held technology for wound assessment
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a multimodal optical imaging system that quantitatively measures tissue biomarkers to characterize healing in diabetic wounds. Diabetic wounds in the US affect more than eight million patients annually with an estimated economic burden of around $30 billion. There is an unmet need for comprehensive imaging tools that can non-invasively measure multiple biomarkers, elucidate underlying tissue changes in diabetic wounds, and provide anatomical and functional information for individualized therapy. In addition, there is a need for objective wound assessment tools to furnish clinicians and caregivers with fast and quantitative methods of determining wound healing/nonhealing status. The proposed device has the potential to assess the risk of developing ulcers and to grade the status of an ulcer as well as to quantify several biomarkers to help guide treatment. Additionally, this technology may be applied to not only diabetic foot ulcers but also burn wounds, surgical wounds, pressure ulcers, and even amputation sites. The benefit may impact wound clinics, home health institutions, and long-term care facilities. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a non-invasive, multimodal, hand-held technology that combines thermal, reflectance, and fluorescence imaging to provide in vivo evaluation of tissue metabolic state, tissue oxygenation, vasculature, and temperature indices. The proposed technology may be used to provide treatment plans that can be adjusted and documented in a patient’s electronic medical record to inform decision-making. Monitoring of biomarkers may give clinicians early indication of complications during wound healing, leading to clearer and more effective interventions or changes in the wound care regime. There have been technological advances within the field of wound care. However, most monitoring technologies focus on a single biomarker. The proposed technology aims to fill in the gaps by combining the measurements of several biomarkers to give a more complete assessment of a wound. The combination of biomarkers plus recent advances in LED and camera technology have allowed for a multi-modal device to now be possible.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to evaluate commercial potential of the development of a multimodal optical imaging system that quantitatively measures tissue biomarkers to characterize healing in chronic wounds with a special focus on diabetic wounds. Diabetic wounds in the US affect more than eight million patients annually with an estimated economic burden of around thirty billion dollars. The hypothesis was that there is an unmet need for comprehensive imaging tools that can non-invasively measure multiple biomarkers, elucidate underlying tissue changes in wounds, and provide anatomical and functional information for individualized therapy.

 We conducted extensive interviews with healthcare professionals, wound care specialists, healthcare and home health facilities, and potential end-users to gather insights into the current challenges in wound assessment and the market's specific needs. These interactions helped the team refine the initial value proposition, identify key features and functionalities, and understand the potential barriers to adoption. The team conducted approximately 108 interviews, starting from a slow pace during the first few weeks and accelerating during the last four weeks of the interviews. The group attended six related conventions and industrial exhibitions across four states to collect, decipher and summarize the results of the discussions.

 One of the critical lessons learned during the NSF I-Corps activity was the importance of understanding the healthcare ecosystem and regulatory landscape. Medical device development requires compliance with various regulations and standards to ensure safety and efficacy. Through interactions with experts in the field, the team would gain insights into the necessary regulatory processes, potential challenges, and best practices for navigating the complex healthcare environment.

 Following the program, we were able to help a startup company (SafetySpect Inc) in their NIH SBIR grant application that they recently submitted to NIH. This SBIR proposal needed a ten page feasibility study and the company benifitted a lot from the lesson we learned from the ICorps and we provided our insight to the company for this.

 


Last Modified: 07/14/2023
Modified by: Kouhyar Tavakolian
